Award.AwardTitle: Aerodynamics of Passive Flight and Probability of Landing Sites

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Accurate prediction of the flight range and landing site of an object descending under the influence of gravitational and aerodynamic forces is relevant to many engineering and science applications. Examples range from forecasting the touchdown locations of re-entry space vehicles to understanding the settlement patterns of marine larvae and their influence on marine population dynamics. While the descent motion follows the laws of classical mechanics, the delicate interplay between the fluid medium and the geometric and material properties of the descending objects makes the exact landing site difficult to predict a priori and, thus, best treated as probabilistic. This award supports fundamental research that aims to develop an experimentally and mathematically tractable framework for studying the coupling between the mechanics of objects descending passively in a fluid medium and the probabilistic outcome of landing sites. This research will draw from techniques developed in several disciplines including solid-fluid interactions, dynamical systems, and probabilistic modeling. This multi-disciplinary research approach will be combined with outreach efforts in the greater Los Angeles area to help broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in research and positively impact engineering and science education.

The descent motion of objects falling in a fluid medium is generally complex, even for regularly shaped objects such as coins and cards. For such objects, four types of descent trajectories have been identified: steady, fluttering, chaotic, or tumbling, depending on the object and fluid properties. This research team will explore the dependence of the probability distribution of landing sites on the type of descent trajectories through carefully designed experiments as well as by developing mathematical and computational models of increasing levels of fidelity to the physical systems. Research efforts will also focus on establishing design principles that an object should fulfill in order to achieve a desired distribution of landing sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Flying organisms, such as birds, insects, and autorotating seeds, rely on unsteady fluid-structure interactions for lift and thrust production.  These interactions have been the subject a great deal of attention in recent experimental and theoretical studies, mostly emphasizing the importance of leading-edge and wake vorticity in force production. Less is known about flight stability in response to environmental disturbances and about the effects of the flyer's properties on flight performance. To study these effects, we developed experimental and computational models of both actuated and passive flight. In one project, we analyzed the hovering dynamics of Λ-shaped flyers in oscillatory flows. We found optimal shapes that minimize the "effort" or flow acceleration needed to hover. We then studied the stability of hovering subject to perturbations and observed a transition from unstable, yet maneuverable, to stable hovering. Importantly, this transition occurs at post-optimal shapes, that is, at increased aerodynamic effort. One should therefore be careful when optimizing for aerodynamic effort without paying attention to motion stability. In so doing, one would obtain optimal flyers that are intrinsically unstable, and thus require active stabilization mechanisms. These results could have profound implications on the interplay between stability and maneuverability in live organisms as well as on the design of man-made vehicles.

In another project, we focused on unpowered flight as a new paradigm for space or terrestrial exploration. Unpowered flight eliminates the need for lift generation and flight control equipment, allowing the development of smaller and cheaper robotic vehicles. To be operationally attractive, reliable predictions of their flight dynamics and landing sites are needed. To establish such predictions, we developed a hierarchy of experimental and analytical models that couple mechanics and probability. We identified interesting transitions in flight behavior and landing probabilities in homogeneous and density-stratified flows. In particular, density stratification significantly enhances the radial dispersion of descending objects, while simultaneously diminishing the fluttering parameters (vertical descent speed, fluttering amplitude and inclination angle). These findings may have significant impact on understanding the behavior of unpowered robotic vehicles, and geological and biological transport where density and temperature variations may occur.

The main findings of this project are disseminated in over twelve journal publications, including two PhD theses, as well as in numerous conferences and workshops such as the American Physical Society, Division of Fluid Dynamics meeting and the Insect Navigation workshop at the Janelia Research Labs.

The intellectual merits of this work also include novel experimental protocols, and original analytical and computational methods for fluid-structure interactions. More generally, our goal is to redefine the hierarchical structure in science and engineering by creating an integrated education and research environment where post-doctoral scholars, graduate and undergraduate students work side-by-side and receive cross-disciplinary training in analytical, computational and experimental methods. Our vision is to educate a new type of global scientist/engineer, one that works in teams to tackle complex problems by combining experimental and computational techniques with rigorous mathematics and physics. 

Outreach efforts included work with underprivileged K-12 schools through USC-led programs and workshops, including training of middle- and high-school teachers participating in a USC-led RET (Research Experience for Teachers) program. We also developed research modules and workshops at the 2015 Hands-On Summer School held at the International Center for Theoretical Physics (ICTP), which focused on the career development and research training of over 60 scientists from the developing world.
